title: Expressive and Scalable Query-based Faceted Search over SPARQL Endpoints

I come from the University of Rain in France.

Another approach is instance based guidance which has the advantage to be more fine grained, but it generally comes with a lower expressivity.
A third property is readability that he's speaking users language under.
As soon as you have a high expressivity or query language, only natural language is really a readable.
Frost property is scalability, that is scaling to the largest endpoint, so this is important to really cope with existing data.

Finally, lost property is portability that is working on new users and pointer on there.
In many cases manual configuration is required which can be very time consuming.

So I think that we need all of them for an effective semantic search, and if we don't have expressivity or scalability then you can't really use it, and if not, you don't have guidance or readability, then not many people can use it.
